name: 柯萊恩
objective: We will begin our study with an overview of theatre itself.  What is theatre?  What are its origins and functions within Western culture?  We will identify genres within the theatre and study the formal choices characteristic of each genre and within every historical period.  We will study the fundamental characteristics of dramatic form including plot, character, action, and setting, as well as the conventions of dramatic genres, specifically tragedy, comedy, and tragicomedy.  We will then turn our attention to the basic repertoire of the actor, the combinations of voice, movement, characterization and emotional shading which help enact the playwright’s vision.  As an adjunct to this, we will look at the basics of theatre: blocking, costuming, make-up, set design and tips on memorization and the efficient use of rehearsal time.  Our major undertaking will be the production of one full-length of several shorter plays by a well-respected playwright.  Each student will be responsible for bringing about the enactment of drama chosen by the class under my guidance.  The course may be a bit of a challenge, but it is a great opportunity for you to create living art of masterpiece quality and to discover the difference between writing done purely as a mode of elementary communication, or for mere entertainment, and writing that is open-ended, provocative, dynamic, haunting, and relentless in its dis/solving of the puzzle of the Real.
schedule:
September 14　　INTRODUCTION: Theatrical period, style, genre.  Discussion of possible plays.  View film, pt. I.  HOMEWORK:  Memorize Hamlet’s speech, “Speak the speech I pray thee…”
September 21　　Choose play.  Basics of characterization: voice, movement.  Trying out new ideas.  Begin selecting roles.  View film, pt. 2.  ASSIGNMENT:  Memorize short scene
September 28　　Practice short scene.  Provisionally select roles.  View film, pt. 3.  ASSIGNMENT:  Prepare for short performance.
October 5　　Performance Revue.  ASSIGNMENT:  Begin memorizing lines, Act One, Scene One (or as appropriate)
October 12　　Introduction to blocking; ass’t director makes crew assignments. ASSIGNMENT:  Continue memorizing lines; work on voice3 charcterization.
October 19　　Blocking; begin assembling materials for sets, costumes, etc. ASSIGNMENT:  Continue memorizing lines, work on movement characterization.
October 26　　Blocking with lines memorized Act One
November 2　　Blocking with lines memorized Act Two
November 9　　 Blocking with lines memorized Act Three
November 16　　Set construction and costuming supervised by ass’t director + individual singers work with musician(s)
November 23　　Scene Rehearsal with sets and costumes supervised by ass’t director + individual singers work with musician(s)
November 30　　Rehearsal  (Mandatory for all students)
December 7　　Rehearsal  (Mandatory of all students)
December 14　　Rehearsal  (Mandatory of all students)
December 21　　Dress Rehearsal/Informal Presentation for English Corner Students  (ABSOLUTELY mandatory of all students)
December 28　　Final Presentation  (ABSOLUTELY mandatory of all students)
